reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game -- the characters are fascinating, and it does have good gameplay.  But this is one of the most cynical MOBAs out there.  Take League of Legends, and cross it with some of the more obnoxious Facebook games.  Energy mechanics to play specific characters (although you can spend in-game cash to reset them), Farmville mechanics to gather resources necessary to get boosts.

Rather than League's runes, masteries, and normal 'Q/W/E/R' levelling, you set up 36 possible levels in their own Rune system -- but those runes have Gacha style randomness, different levels of rarity / effectiveness, and you can combine runes together to level them up to level 5.  These set up the level up bonuses that you get in match -- and their strength also contributes to the normal level up bonuses you get.

At all steps you're given incentives to pay money -- money can get you double XP towards your characters to increase their stats in a small way, double your rune drops, turn off the green (common, and incredibly weak) drops entirely, and many other things.  While this game is ostensibly free to play...it's incredibly pay to win, as well.  A person who spends money can buy some legendary runes to start off with that are a good headstart, buy the ability to pick up runes more easily, and buy the ability to get their resources faster to level things up.

The gameplay is fun...but I can't continue to play it with just how horrible the metagame is.  Add to this the fact that the game is mostly popular in Russia and other Asian countries, with no regional servers--so you will almost always be matched with 3 or 4 players that do not speak your language, and it's just not for me anymore.

A foreword about me: I played a lot of DotA back when it was called DotA 3.3 as a WarCraft 3 non-expansion custom map. I played succeeding versions up to 3.7, Danite's Hell, and those that supported game modes such as -aram. I've also been a progression and hardmore raider in WoW and SWTOR. I play League of Legends casually.

Now about Prime World:

This is a MOBA but it's not just a MOBA.

It has the grind of an MMO that both casual and hardcore players can enjoy.

Casuals might like the city-building and city-management aspects of the game. You build buildings and order them to produce wood, ore, food, silver, crystals, or gold (cash shop currency). These resources can be used to buy heroes (like LoL champions), buy hero skins, buy talents, upgrade buildings, upgrade talents, send heroes on quests at the tavern, or rest heroes at the inn (heroes need to rest after a match or quest).

Casuals might also like the Zuma-type game in the actual MOBA part of the game. On the 5v5 map, you can have 3 laners, 1 jungler, and 1 playing Zuma, which helps your team maximize everybody's XP gain. When playing Zuma, a successful game rewards you with a one-time consumable scroll that you can send to anyone on your team, including yourself. The spell on the scroll, and the strength of the spell, is something you select before each Zuma game. For instance, you could start the 5v5 match and play Zuma to create a level 1 healing scroll for your jungler, or a level 5 AoE damage scroll for an early lane push.

reviewText:
Prime World suffers from a few major problems.

1: It is free to play with mechanics that strongly benefit paying customers.
2: It is a MOBA. Yes this is a problem. MOBAs aren't inherently bad games but they are made so by the horrid userbase that plays them. People are far too competetive and simply joining random games with the intent of having fun seems rare/impossible most of the time. The game is targetted at hardcore gamers so if you aren't a hardcore MOBA gamer stay away.
3: Progression feels too grindy. Games like this, which rely on players being put on fairly equal footing, stick in leveling+progression almost arbitrarily. Sure your heroes get stronger but you're only ever put onto the playing field with others in your general tier of power, which makes progression much less about empowering your character and more about pigeon-holing you against stronger opponents (the more you play the more competetive+less fun the game becomes).

Basically stay away from this game if you're not a hardcore MOBA player. It is just not fun for casual play.

reviewText:
Prime World - An outstanding MOBA
Hey guys,

I've been playing Prime World for 2 months now or in other words ~500 hours of playing time. As I played League of Legends and DotA2 before I was wondering what another MOBA might bring to the table to make me stick with it.
But I can tell you: There were things that did.

First of all a short overview:

+ Several unique Heros all with their own playstyle
+ Different game modes
+ Talent-System
+ Nice graphics
+ Castle-System
+ Easy to learn
+ Mostly polite and nice gamers around there

- Low playerbase -> therfor sometimes real terrible matchmaking
- Talent-System (yes it's also negative sometimes, more on that later)


As you might know Prime World is another MOBA title. But there are two things that are making this one really unique. The Talent-System and the Castle-System.

For the Castle-System: It is nothing spectacular and reminds me of some tycoon style games on facebook. You have your buildings to get some additional Income or Talents. Productions take from 30 Minutes up to 23 hours. But it's fun to organize and manage your castle during your Queue Times.

The Talent-System is what makes the game unique to play. There is no exp or gold in the matches, only prime. With Prime you can unlock the heros talents which you organize and plan in the castle before even going to the battlefield. This offers you some tactical decision making aswell as the opportunity to play heros in really different ways. Also you can determinate if you want to specialize on something with your hero or be more like an allrounder.
After every match you get some talents. Some of those are more common, some of those are really rare and therfor more powerful.
For me it is really fun to play many matches and it's awesome to finally get a much desired Talent after many games. But I guess it can also be really frustrating, especially as the quality of your heros talents also determinates the power of your hero ingame. So if you're exactly on the same skill level like your opponent and even playing the same hero, but he is epic talented and you are only common you will lose. So it takes some time to get heros strong. If you like this talent farming, like me, it's awesome for sure, but if you just want a smooth start in the game without any disadvantages at start you should probably play DotA2 instead.

What the game mostly suffers from is its low playerbase. The matchmaking really sucks often because there are just not enough players to make it work.
Also when you start playing the game you get Tutorial Quests. One of them is winning 10 pvp games. You have a own Queue for people having this quest pending which would be nice if there just were some more of them. This way new players face terrible queue times (1h+) and most likely quit before even giving the game the chance it deserves for sure. You can get around this by looking for people in the world chat who already finished this quest and ask them to group with you. But this way you get much higher opponents which might not only be frustrating, but also tends to make reaching 10 wins a real pain in the ♥♥♥.

Still I like this MOBA most of all those out there, as it is more about teamwork and tactical decision making than individual skill, like in League or DotA. Hopefully it will at some point get the love it deserves and the playerbase to run smooth. There is so much potential and it is definitely worth a try!

reviewText:
First I thought this was a random MOBA type game, but it's not. Besides the usual regular map similar to other games, it brings several other modes, including an Outpost mode where you battle 3x3 on a one lane area, a native land arena, where your abilities are stronger depending on how much land your team owns, a dragon 4x4 fight where you battle mobs towards the middle, fight the dragon then get to fight the other team and a zombie arena where your enemies are turned to zombies allied with you when they die.
As a major difference from regular MOBAs, the hero does not need to buy artifacts inside the fighting game, but they get time to arrange their talents before the battle in their town. After each battle you win some talents and you can progress your heroes using these talents creating an unique hero. The player can add abilities to their hero with these talents and alter the stats to their desire. Of course for newer players some suggested stats that a hero usually uses are highlighted so the player can have an idea of what talents they could try.
Besides this hero fighting game, the game offers a base building mechanic. I shall admit that this isn't extremely polished and could use some work, but the idea is a good one. The base acts as a home for the heroes, where you can produce talents and train your heroes.

The game mixes a combination of MOBA, rts, and 'MMORPG' elements, sometimes a little inneffectioally. Regardless, its a fun game, and the leveling is loose like Heroes of the Storm, with the ability to craft your own custom hero, essentially, with the classes being more a 'guide' than hard core choice.

Perhaps not as competitive as other MOBAs, one to be enjoyed by more casual or grind-enjoying enthusiasts. The one downside is the lack of NA population, resulting in quite alot of matches with Russians.

reviewText: I love this game, and hate it, but mostly love it. I love it because there is so much progression, you are leveling up stuff all the time. You have a castle and a Lord(you) that you level up, buildings in the castle you level, you have champs that you level up, and you level up their gear(called talents), and you can make/join a clan, and level that up. Gameplay is fun, and you have plenty PvE to do. You can do challenge maps for gear, and various bot games. So why hate it at all? PvP. You must understand that it is not balanced, and that doesn't mean it's bad. Right now the game is set to match you up based on your performance, based on wins. However, gear and character level play a huge role in balance. Gear is divided into levels, like World of Warcraft and other games, based on color and stats. Yellow gear, Green, Blue, Purple, Orange, and each piece has different active or passive abilities or stat increases, as well as the ability to boost your overall stats. Your character has a power rating based on gear score, so you may be in all yellow and green gear with a 1200 power score, and have to fight someone in rare and epic gear whose character level may also be higher, and sometimes, your entire team will be lower level and outgeared, even though your ranking may be similar. Each character level lets you put a couple skill points into your character, so you may face the same champ in lane as you, similarly geared, but if the level difference going in is significant, you are weaker. Skill can overcome that, but skill can't overcome both significant level and gear differences. Factor in that you will often have quitters and afkers, and at the moment no way to report them, and you could easily find yourself wanting to punch a hole in the wall.\nBut if you know that is the way it is, and don't expect that just cause you are better skilled but may still lose...a lot, then you will have fun, imo.

reviewText:
Interesting. There are so many things in one game. However, I think Prime World Thrones tries to be too many things at once and doesn't integrate it together. I believe they just found a whole bunch of concepts from click-farming, MOBA, MMORPG and city building and just mashed it all up into PW:T. It's horrible.

PROS
1. Fun Stuff
There are mini-games that resembe Zuma, a bubble popping game that has you shooting bubbles to makes combine 3 of a colour on a snake-like trail.

2. Defense maps / Challenges
Hordes of monsters just keep pouring on and you have got to kill them all.

3. Easy unlocking of heroes
There are quests you can do in the other mini-games that unlock the heroes. As long as you reach level 36 and have enough silver, you should be able to get all the heroes. However, locking the core mechanic of the game away from players is mostly stupidity on the developer's end.

CONS
1. Doesn't gel
All the mini-games do not gel. How could you have a Zuma game in the middle of a MOBA battle just to produce a scroll? That will mean 1 afk player aiming to build a specific scroll.

2. Pay-to-Win
You actually have to rest your hero so that you can use him. His Vigour needs to be restored at a Spa. Not only that, they make you buy things called Talents to upgrade your hero with gold (cash currency). Talents are special skills that you get in-game when you level up during MOBA combat, a wrong combination will make you very weak or very strong.

3. City Builder
This begun to get pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ once I started seeing a need to click-farm and build a city. You have to play multiple games in that don't make sense.

You build a city to produce housing, food, silver, thread, Prime and a spa.

What are they trying to do with this?

4. Hero Upgrading
There are Mastery points, which are stat points, and Talents that severely imbalance a game. If you play the game till max level and you get enough Master points, your hero's stats will be far superior to another player's. If you get super rare and powerful Talents that you equip on your hero, you will also be imbalanced.

5. Hero Lists
Mirror Image. The same heroes for the Imperium are in Adornia, just with different skins.

reviewerDisplayName: You have to let it go
reviewText:
Not so much a straight up recommendation as a bit of a review. I saw this MOBA had just released and decided to give it a whirl, at least for a few bot matches. The RTS aspects of building up your base seem fairly fleshed out and not too terribly pay-to-win as they are pay for convenience. Though I imagine times go up rather exponentially as you play more of the game.

The Skill systems is rather unique in that, as opposed to having set skills, you equip different skills in a tree of skills and you level up 1-36, picking and choosing which skills you prioritize over others. This lends itself to having no item system for stats as all stats are gained via purchasing of talents. Purchasing talents is as easy as collecting 'Primer' which acts as a universal currency for leveling up or potions/scrolls.

The Hero variety is actually rather surprising, though both sides are basically carbon copies of each other. There are some unique ideas in some of the hero design in that some have skills that follow your cursor around or there is one that has a pet that you can interchange with at will. The only issue is that unlocking all of these heroes will either take some money upfront or a decent time investment. Skins are actually sort of cool in that they are actual redesigns of the hero, not solely a new set of armor. Like one of the starter Heroes has a male and female skin as well as an Shogun inspired skin that replaces it with a Shogun style person.

Gameplay itself is like League of Legends with some Dota spruced in. The combat is heavily League of Legends, while the river is more like Dota with Runes. The items are also more dota like in that you have TP scrolls and potions are a lot less throw away than they are in league due to cost affecting your leveling as well. There are multiple gamemodes, of which I have played the 3v3 and 5v5 models. The Flagpole system is fairly unique in that it allows teleportation via your Teleport skill that is present on all heroes to any region covered by a flagpole you control.

Overall, it's a pretty average MOBA. A good time waster, if nothing else. A solid 7/10.

reviewText:
At first glance the game looks promising. A wide variety of talents to assign to your hero and with that a Flametail can be very different from another Flametail, they don't even have to look the same. Despite all the negative reviews I decided to download and give it a shot ... but will uninstall now.

Base line is: If you are new to MOBA ... don't even try. If you don't want to spend a lot of money ... don't play THIS game. If you're not good in English (or Russian) ... don't try this one. If you are easily fed up and annoyed with your fellow players ... really, do everyone a favour and don't strain your nerves on this one, cause the matchmaking is useless and you will get fed up and angry.

To make it more detailed:

There is good stuff, don't get me wrong. I do like the many different heroes, the look of the game, the varieties of talents and I even like the castle and building it all, earning silver, silk and other ressources to improve your castle. I quite enjoyed the PvE aspect (yes, I know, it's a MOBA and not a single-player RPG or god knows what ^^) as it helps to get to know your hero and the way the game is played.
However. Once you have the first PvP quests the fun is over. The matchmaking is indeed catastrophic. I never had to wait long, but honestly I'd prefer to wait some more rather than being matched up against a bunch of players that have high ranking heroes with great talents while I'm having a yellow, basic hero with mainly crappy talents. There is no kick- or vote-off-the-team-option for AFK players and there is a great deal of people who either tab out of the game and forget they entered the queue or who only need a win for a quest and decide to let the others do the work and let the programme run while they go do something else.
So you are one or two men down already and matched up against an active 5-player-team with at least one monster hero on their side. Perfect recipe for fed up players and for rudeness. The verbal abuse this community is producing, cursing, shouting, screaming at the 'noobs' is seriously discouraging. Usually they are experienced players levelling up a lower character and having better talents than someone who just started and yes, they are fed up for good reason but it's not the noobs fault - and I'm including myself - that the matchmaking in the game is so bad. If it's your second or third match you make mistakes and you act stupid simply because you don't know any better. And the rudeness level goes from 0 to 100 within the first death in the own ranks no matter who died. Seen that many times, unfortunately.

Of course you can enhance your chances and game experience a lot. You just need to spend enough money on gold to buy the best heroes and talents real money can buy. Of course a F2P game needs some sort of revenue to survive but this way the game is extremely unbalanced.

There is also little in terms of introduction to the different styles of heroes and such. They have different strengths and weaknesses, but that's for you to figure out (or read up on. I'm sure there's a ton of guides) but if you're not someone who wants to read up for ages before even attempting to play, you're pretty much lost.

Anyway, there's some good ideas behind this, but as it stands at the moment, I would not recommend it to anyone and I deleted the game now. Shame, really, but I play to have fun and not read people shouting and coursing at each other in the worst way ever (and the mature language filter is not helping, either).

Pros:

reviewText:
Not so much a straight up recommendation as a bit of a review. I saw this MOBA had just released and decided to give it a whirl, at least for a few bot matches. The RTS aspects of building up your base seem fairly fleshed out and not too terribly pay-to-win as they are pay for convenience. Though I imagine times go up rather exponentially as you play more of the game.

The Skill systems is rather unique in that, as opposed to having set skills, you equip different skills in a tree of skills and you level up 1-36, picking and choosing which skills you prioritize over others. This lends itself to having no item system for stats as all stats are gained via purchasing of talents. Purchasing talents is as easy as collecting 'Primer' which acts as a universal currency for leveling up or potions/scrolls.

The Hero variety is actually rather surprising, though both sides are basically carbon copies of each other. There are some unique ideas in some of the hero design in that some have skills that follow your cursor around or there is one that has a pet that you can interchange with at will. The only issue is that unlocking all of these heroes will either take some money upfront or a decent time investment. Skins are actually sort of cool in that they are actual redesigns of the hero, not solely a new set of armor. Like one of the starter Heroes has a male and female skin as well as an Shogun inspired skin that replaces it with a Shogun style person.

Gameplay itself is like League of Legends with some Dota spruced in. The combat is heavily League of Legends, while the river is more like Dota with Runes. The items are also more dota like in that you have TP scrolls and potions are a lot less throw away than they are in league due to cost affecting your leveling as well. There are multiple gamemodes, of which I have played the 3v3 and 5v5 models. The Flagpole system is fairly unique in that it allows teleportation via your Teleport skill that is present on all heroes to any region covered by a flagpole you control.

Overall, it's a pretty average MOBA. A good time waster, if nothing else. A solid 7/10.

column28: you know about the Talents system. I'm only pointing out one thing that would immediately invalidate the way Nival is operating the system right now: paying real money to unassign talents. Here comes the pay-to-be-able-to-play nature of the game (nope it's not even pay-to-win any more
column29: mind you):\n\n- When a talent is put on a hero
column30: it is assigned (or "bound") to that hero. Only he/she can use the talent.\n\n- For purple and orange talents (Epic and Exclusive talents AKA your essentials for higher ELO matches) you will need to pay a certain amount of gold (the in-game currency bought by real money) to "unassign" ("unbind") the talent. Ofc
column31: Orange is rarer than purple so you will need to pay more to unassign.\n\n- The limitation of this is that players cannot freely experiment with new builds. Sure they provide you with this "Talent Calculator" app to see how the different combinations of Talents affect your heroes' attributes; however

- Which brings you to the question of whether this game is a MOBA or not. I don't believe in pay-to-win MOBA because MOBA is about fair competition: skill and skill alone should determine the outcome of matches.

- WHAT IS WORSE about this "pay-to-unassign" system is that every time a new patch comes out (obviously with "re-balancing" fixes to heroes
column37: veteran players who have quite an established playstyle (and sets of talents for their heroes) are likely to be FORCED to swap in/swap out purple/orange talents to suit the new meta brought about by the new patch. Consequently
column38: they are PAYING real money just to be able to continue playing the game
column39: thereby making them cows for Nival to milk. Forcefully so
column41: there are workarounds to these changes in meta which do not require you to pay gold. However
column42: they are all very tedious methods which will require certain trade-offs. Play the game for a while and you will understand what i'm saying.\n\nThe bottom line: This game is worth a shot
column43: but if you are coming in with an "everything-is-free" mindset then you are in for a hard time. And did i forget to mention high ping issue with this game? Somehow high ping
column44: disconnection and reconnect issues really plague the game as of the moment. I can only hope Nival will do something about it."
